Pros:
Strong multimodal skills (text, image, video). 

Deep AWS integration (Bedrock). 

Good balance of cost and performance.
Cons:
Proprietary and locked to AWS. 

Video analysis ignores audio. 

Less raw reasoning power than top-tier GPT-5 or Claude 4 Opus.
Common Agent Uses:
Business intelligence agents: Analyzing sales videos, charts, and reports within AWS. 

Cloud automation agents: Managing and orchestrating AWS resources.

Pros:
Very fast and low-cost multimodal model. 

Optimized for interactive, real-time applications.
Cons:
Less accurate than Nova Pro. 

Not intended for highly complex reasoning.
Common Agent Uses:
Customer service agents: Handling high-volume, real-time text and image queries. 

Content moderation agents: Rapidly scanning user-submitted images.

Pros:
Extremely cheap and fast for text-only tasks. 

Optimized for low latency and high throughput.
Cons:
Text-only; no vision or audio capabilities. 

The weakest model in the Nova family.
Common Agent Uses:
Simple API agents: Formatting data, classifying text, or powering simple chatbots. 

Router agents: Quickly assessing a user's intent before passing to a larger model.

Pros:
Open-weight (MoE: 17B active of 400B total). 

Frontier performance that rivals closed models. 

Natively multimodal (text, image). 

No API cost if self-hosted.
Cons:
Requires significant hardware and technical skill to self-host. 

No built-in safety/moderation layer (requires self-implementation).
Common Agent Uses:
Private/on-premise agents: Operating inside a company's firewall for maximum data privacy. 

Custom-trained agents: Fine-tuned on proprietary data for specialized tasks (e.g., medical research).

Pros:
Open-weight (MoE). 

Massive 10M token context window. 

Excellent for processing entire codebases or multiple large documents.
Cons:
Also requires significant hardware to run. 

Slower than Maverick due to its focus on long context.
Common Agent Uses:
Research agents: Reading and summarizing multiple technical papers or books. 

Coding agents: Analyzing and refactoring an entire large-scale software project.

Pros:
State-of-the-art reasoning and coding. 

"Constitutional AI" provides strong safety and reliability. 

Excels at complex, multi-step tasks.
Cons:
Very expensive; the highest-cost model. 

Proprietary. 

Safety alignment can sometimes be restrictive.
Common Agent Uses:
High-stakes enterprise agents: Handling sensitive legal, financial, or medical data. 

Autonomous coding agents: Planning and executing complex software development tasks.

Pros:
Excellent balance of price and performance. 

Nearly as capable as Opus but significantly cheaper and faster.
Cons:
Proprietary. 

Not quite as powerful as Opus for the most complex reasoning.
Common Agent Uses:
Advanced workflow agents: Powering the "brains" of most production-grade business automations. 

Complex customer service agents: Handling multi-turn, nuanced conversations.

Pros:
Adds "Computer Use" (can control a browser/OS). 

"Extended Thinking" allows it to reason before answering. 

Best-in-class for agentic tasks.
Cons:
Proprietary. 

More expensive than Claude 4 Sonnet. 

"Computer Use" features can have a steep learning curve.
Common Agent Uses:
Autonomous web agents: Browsing websites, filling out forms, and extracting data. 

Proactive assistant agents: Monitoring systems and taking action without a prompt.

Pros:
High-speed, cost-effective models. 

The 3.7 version introduced early "extended thinking" capabilities. 

Great for scaling.
Cons:
Proprietary. 

Outclassed by the Claude 4 and 4.5 families in reasoning and agentic skill.
Common Agent Uses: Mid-complexity agents: Tasks that need more power than Haiku but not the cost of Sonnet 4.5 (e.g., drafting long-form content, summarizing meetings).

Pros:
Adds "Computer Use" and "Extended Thinking" to the fast/cheap tier. 

Incredibly fast and affordable for its capabilities.
Cons:
Proprietary. 

Much less accurate than Sonnet/Opus; can fail at complex tasks.
Common Agent Uses:
Simple autonomous agents: Performing basic, repetitive UI tasks (e.g., "login and download this report"). 

Scalable data extraction agents.

Pros:
Extremely fast and low-cost (text, image). 

The "entry-level" Claude model.
Cons:
Proprietary. 

No advanced agentic skills (like computer use). 

Low reasoning power; struggles with nuance.
Common Agent Uses:
Simple RAG agents: Quickly pulling information from a knowledge base. 

Triage/classification agents.

Pros:
Top-tier performance in reasoning, coding, and problem-solving. 

"Thinking" modes allow for dynamic control over reasoning/cost. 

Robust and reliable API.
Cons:
Proprietary and high-cost. 

Can be slower than competitors for its "high thinking" modes.
Common Agent Uses:
"God-mode" agents: The central controller for complex agent swarms. 

Autonomous problem-solving agents: Given a high-level goal, it can plan and execute all steps.

Pros:
Excellent balance of speed, cost, and intelligence. 

The "Sonnet" or "Pro" equivalent in the GPT-5 family. 

Also features "Thinking" modes.
Cons:
Proprietary. 

Still more expensive than "nano" or "lite" tiers.
Common Agent Uses:
Primary agent "brain": Used for most production workflows that require reliable, smart responses. 

Advanced data analysis agents.

Pros:
Very fast and very low-cost. 

Optimized for high-throughput tasks. 

Surprisingly capable for its size.
Cons:
Proprietary. 

Low reasoning power; not suitable for complex tasks on its own.
Common Agent Uses: "Worker" or "Specialist" agents: Handling simple, repetitive tasks given by a larger agent (e.g., "summarize this text," "check this code for syntax errors").

Pros:
A strong, reliable flagship model (successor to GPT-4o). 

Well-understood and battle-tested.
Cons:
Proprietary. 

Generally surpassed by the GPT-5 family in performance and efficiency.
Common Agent Uses: Legacy agents: Powering established workflows built before GPT-5's release.

Pros: Faster, cheaper versions of GPT 4.1.
Cons:
Proprietary. 

Largely made obsolete by the more capable and efficient GPT-5 nano.
Common Agent Uses: Low-cost agents: Used in applications where upgrading to the GPT-5 stack isn't a priority.

Pros:
Massive 1M+ token context window. 

Deep integration with Google ecosystem (Workspace, Cloud). 

Excellent at processing and reasoning over huge datasets (code, video, text).
Cons:
Proprietary. 

Can be verbose. 

Best features are locked into the Google Cloud ecosystem.
Common Agent Uses:
Productivity agents: Managing your Gmail, Drive, and Calendar. 

Long-context research agents: Analyzing entire repositories or 10-hour videos.

Pros:
Extremely fast and cost-effective. 

Also supports a 1M token context window. 

Optimized for speed in long-context tasks.
Cons:
Proprietary. 

Much lower reasoning quality than Pro, especially in long-context tasks.
Common Agent Uses:
Real-time conversational agents: Powering chatbots that need to reference large documents instantly. 

High-speed RAG agents.

Pros:
Advanced Agentic Skills: Supports "Thinking" mode (allowing it to reason before answering), code execution, and Google Search grounding. 

Larger Output: Has a much larger output limit (65.5K tokens) than its predecessor. 

Better Instruction Following: More accurate, less "preachy" in tone, and better at being concise.
Cons:
Proprietary. 

"Thinking" mode, while more powerful, can increase latency and cost compared to non-thinking operation. 

More expensive than the 2.0 version.
Common Agent Uses:
Smarter "Worker" Agents: Can be given complex instructions to perform tasks like running code or verifying information. 

Dynamic Workflow Agents: Used in agentic pipelines that require decision-making. 

Small-scale Reasoning Agents: Handling simple logic or analysis tasks.

Pros:
Extreme Speed & Low Cost: One of the fastest and cheapest models on the market, optimized for high throughput. 

Excellent for RAG: Its speed and 1M token context window make it ideal for high-volume RAG at a low cost. 

Very Low Latency: Perfect for real-time, interactive applications.
Cons:
Proprietary. 

No Advanced Skills: Does not support "Thinking" mode, code execution, or grounding. 

Limited Reasoning: Has very low reasoning power; not for complex tasks. 

Small Output Limit: Restricted to a smaller 8.2K token output.
Common Agent Uses:
Simple "Worker" Agents: Used in a swarm to perform high-volume, simple tasks (e.g., "format this data," "classify this email"). 

Real-time Voice Agents: Powering conversational AI where low latency is more important than deep intelligence. 

Triage/Router Agents: Quickly assessing user intent before routing to a more powerful model.
